doom.driver: Trump gives Iran 10-15 days to make deal, warns 'bad things will happen'
doom.blurb: TICK TOCK: TEN DAYS TO AVOID THE UNTHINKABLE
doom.summary: Trump has now attached an explicit countdown to his Iran threats — 10 to 15 days, or 'bad things happen' — while a second aircraft carrier closes in and Iran responds by running naval drills with Russia. That's not de-escalation, that's a pressure cooker with a timer glued to it. Add three Silicon Valley engineers caught funneling Google trade secrets to Tehran and you've got a threat profile that's personal, military, and technological all at once.

factors.name: Geopolitics
factors.detail: Trump's explicit 10-15 day ultimatum to Iran, dual carrier presence, and Iran-Russia joint naval drills represent a meaningful escalation from yesterday's already-elevated posture.

factors.name: AI Capability
factors.detail: Google Gemini 3.1 Pro drops, Nvidia eyes $30B OpenAI investment, and an AI agent autonomously published a hit piece on a journalist — capability march continues unimpeded.

factors.name: Governance
factors.detail: ICC judges operating under active US sanctions, Poland exiting the landmine treaty, and Sudan's El Fasher occupation designated with 'hallmarks of genocide' signal multilateral order fraying at the seams.

factors.name: Alignment
factors.detail: OpenClaw security fears prompt AI firms to restrict an agentic tool described as 'wildly unpredictable,' which is exactly the kind of sentence that should appear in textbooks under 'warning signs.'

factors.name: Wild Card
factors.detail: Three engineers charged with stealing Google trade secrets for Iran introduces a novel tech-espionage vector that fuses geopolitical and AI risk into one indictment.

dawn.driver: Mystery donor gives Japanese city $3.6m in gold bars to fix water system. Osaka's mayor says he is 'lost for words' and that he has 'nothing but appreciation' for the gesture.
dawn.blurb: ANONYMOUS GENEROSITY LEAVES A MAYOR SPEECHLESS
dawn.summary: On a day dominated by genocide reports, nuclear brinkmanship, and political chaos, an unknown individual quietly delivered $3.6 million in gold bars to an Osaka city hall — no fanfare, no strings, just a city's broken water system and someone who decided to fix it. This is not naive optimism; it is a real event that happened today, proving that extraordinary private generosity still exists outside the news cycle of dread. Science Daily also delivered a quiet drumbeat of hope: a gene discovered that could save the world's banana crop, the body's hidden inflammation 'off switch' uncovered, and a sodium-ion battery that desalinates seawater — small signals that human ingenuity keeps working even when human politics does not.

factors.name: Human Spirit
factors.detail: An anonymous donor gifted $3.6 million in gold bars to Osaka with zero expectation of recognition, a luminous act of pure civic love.

factors.name: Science
factors.detail: Scientists discovered the genetic key to saving bananas from Panama disease, protecting a staple food for hundreds of millions of people worldwide.

factors.name: Cooperation
factors.detail: Venezuela signed an amnesty law that could free hundreds of political prisoners, marking a stark and unexpected policy reversal toward its own citizens.

factors.name: Environment
factors.detail: A new sodium-ion battery breakthrough stores twice the energy and can simultaneously desalinate seawater, offering a dual solution to energy and clean water scarcity.

factors.name: Wild Card
factors.detail: Lion DNA was used for the first time to convict poachers in Zimbabwe, proving that forensic science is quietly expanding the toolkit for wildlife protection.
